_prev_prog_2.Description: Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY-CARROLL SERVICE COMPANY FORRESTON FACILITY

Note that this facility was the property of BLACKHAWK FS and they have since gone out of business.                                              

1. Facility accidntal relaease and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of Carroll Service Company are committed tot he prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should accur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minnimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.

The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonis is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 112,000 pounds, this would include the large tank and the nurse tanks.

3. The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.

The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the storage tank released as a gas over a 10 minute period.  The maximum quantity released would be 56,000 pounds, this would represent the volume of the largest storage tank as limited by design.

The distance to the endpoint of .14 mg/L for the worst-case scenario is .84 miles.

The alternative release scenario based on the most likely potential incident is a release from a break in a transfer hose.

The distance to the endpoint of .14 mg/L for the alternative scenario is .1 miles.  This release has the possibility of extending beyond the facility boundaries.

4. The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention

Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requiarements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

5. Five year accident history.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

6. The emergency response program.

The facility has:
-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);
-a written emergency response plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

7. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is and on=going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safetly recommendations for implementation at this time.


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR A NURSE TANK

The storage of an anhydrous ammonia nurse tank is 1,000 gallon.  The maximum pounds that can be stored is 5,000 pounds.

The worst case scenario would be the release of the nurse tanks entire contents as a goas over 90 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 5000 pounds which represents the volume of the nurse tank or as limited by design standards.

The distance to the endpoint of .14 mg/L for the worst-case scenario is .36 miles.

The alternative release scenario based on the most likely po

tential incident is a release from a failed safety valve.  There is no emergency shutdown considered to limit the amount of product released.

The distance to the endpoint of .14 mg/L for the alternative scenario is .1 miles.  This release has the possibility of reaching beyond the facility boundary.  The release rate is 52 lbs/min.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1". Published by The American National Standards Institue, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident program.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
-Have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor
-To our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter inplace, property damage, or environmental damage.

The emergency response program.
The facility has:
-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)>

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Forreston Fire Department and the Ogle County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and the Ogle County LEPC.

Planned chages to improve safety:
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are n
o specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
